author: jtraglia
content: Where does the value for [`MAX_REQUEST_DATA_COLUMN_SIDECARS`](https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/e13c58d59da21d12f3e5bda8af8427afab1c0c1e/configs/mainnet.yaml#L170) come from? It's `MAX_REQUEST_BLOCKS_DENEB * NUMBER_OF_COLUMNS`, right? I feel like maybe this isn't enough. Shouldn't it be `MAX_REQUEST_BLOCKS_DENEB * NUMBER_OF_COLUMNS * MAX_BLOBS_PER_BLOCK`? cc <@520034910149410861>

author: agnxsh
content: Wait, but why do i need Max blobs per block here?

author: agnxsh
content: 1 block can have (Number of columns) max columns, hence (Max request blocks) will have at max (Max request blocks * number of columns)  max columns?

author: agnxsh
content: Nope that was a different issue my bad

author: agnxsh
content: Independent of blob count

author: agnxsh
content: Correct me if I‚Äôm wrong

author: jtraglia
content:
So for deneb/electra, the limit is based on the number of blobs. For example:
```
MAX_REQUEST_BLOB_SIDECARS_ELECTRA = MAX_REQUEST_BLOCKS_DENEB * MAX_BLOBS_PER_BLOCK_ELECTRA
```
This allows a node to request all of the blobs for those blocks it received. With the current `MAX_REQUEST_DATA_COLUMN_SIDECARS` this is no longer the case. If you receive 128 blocks, you'll need to make several data column sidecar requests.

author: jtraglia
content: Oh my. Nevermind. Please disregard. Just a brain fart. The number of columns will stay the same regardless of blob count.

author: agnxsh
content:
let's say my blob count is 6, 9, 14, 24, ...(i don't know the highest limit, i think 64 for erasure coding)
my max number of columns will be 128

author: agnxsh
content: no worries

author: 0xunclebill
content:
I'm trying to test higher blob count scenarios via spamoor

I've added this to my config, but spamoor died on me around slot 45
```
spamoor_params:
  image: ethpandaops/spamoor:blob-v1
  spammers:
    - scenario: blob-combined
      config:
        throughput: 10
        sidecars: 2
        blob_v1_percent: 100
```

right before it dies i start seeing these error warnings

```
 level=warning msg="could not load tx receipt: not found" client="172.16.0.11:8545" txhash=0xc2528e7858373711e1fc4b1812e3d8ae2ba8be91737e8e3ddef104b4892e396c
```

anyone else facing similar issues? am i doing something wrong?

author: pk910

author: 0xunclebill
content:
was able to recreate the issue with this config

fwiw I was running with ` --image-download always`

```
participants_matrix:
  el:
    - el_type: geth
      el_image: ethpandaops/geth:marius-engine-getblobs-v2
  cl:
    - cl_type: lighthouse
      cl_image: ethpandaops/lighthouse:peerdas-devnet-6
      supernode: true
    - cl_type: lighthouse
      cl_image: ethpandaops/lighthouse:peerdas-devnet-6
      supernode: false
network_params:
  electra_fork_epoch: 0
  fulu_fork_epoch: 1
  max_blobs_per_block_fulu: 64
  target_blobs_per_block_fulu: 48
  num_validator_keys_per_node: 256
additional_services:
  - dora
  - spamoor
spamoor_params:
  image: ethpandaops/spamoor:blob-v1
  spammers:
    - scenario: blob-combined
      config:
        throughput: 10
        sidecars: 2
        blob_v1_percent: 100
```

author: pk910
content:
thx, was able to reproduce it üôÇ
the problem is that geth doesn't accept V1 blob transactions yet, but spamoor sends all transactions as v1 after fulu activation.
so all transactions are rejected as there are only geth pairs. I'm not sure why there's no error response shown.. still checking.,

You can set `blob_v1_percent: 0` to avoid this problem with geth only networks. Spamoor will send all txs as v0 then.
